io.libraft.algorithm
Class RaftAlgorithm

java.lang.Object
  io.libraft.algorithm.RaftAlgorithm
All Implemented Interfaces:
RPCReceiver, Raft
public final class RaftAlgorithm
extends Object
implements RPCReceiver, Raft

Raft distributed consensus algorithm.

An instance of this component is instantiated by each Raft server in the Raft cluster. Clients use Raft to interact with RaftAlgorithm. Messages to other servers in the Raft cluster are sent via a RPCSender, and incoming messages are consumed via the RPCReceiver interface. Raft algorithm metadata is stored in an instance of a Store and LogEntry instances are persisted to the durable Log. This component uses a Timer to schedule tasks for future execution.

Thread Safety

This class is thread-safe.

Thread-safety is achieved through use of a 'big lock', which serializes operations on RaftAlgorithm. The lock is held during all calls to external subsystems (RPCSender, Store, Log, Timer), while processing incoming messages from RPCReceiver, and while clients are notified of committed log entries via RaftListener.applyCommand(long, io.libraft.Command).

Unfortunately this design is prone to deadlocks. For example, the following lock structure:

  • big lock: RaftAlgorithm
  • client lock: Raft, RaftListener
Could result in a deadlock during the following call sequence: 

     RPCReceiver                  RaftAlgorithm                 RaftListener                       Raft
     -----------                  -------------                 ------------                       ----
         |                             |                             |                              |
         | -- onAppendEntriesReply --> |                             |                              |
         |   [ acquire 'big lock' ]    |                             |                              |
         |                             |                             |                              |
         |                             |                             |                              |
         |                             |                   [ acquire 'client lock' ]                |
         |                             | <-----------------------submitCommand--------------------- |
         |                             |                   [  wait for 'big lock'  ]                |
         |                             |                             |                              |
         |                             |                             |                              |
         |                             |  ------ applyCommand -----> |                              |
         |                             |  [ wait for 'client lock' ] |                              |
         |                             |                             |                              |
Clients should account for this in designing and implementing their locking mechanisms.

RaftListener Callbacks

RaftAlgorithm expects that all calls to RaftListener complete without throwing. This implementation will terminate the JVM with a RaftConstants.UNCAUGHT_THROWABLE_EXIT_CODE exit code on any uncaught listener exception. This behaviour was chosen because RaftAlgorithm cannot guarantee that the overall system (which includes both RaftAlgorithm and client code) is in a consistent state and will continue to operate correctly after an unhandled error.

Exception Handling

There are four major entry points into RaftAlgorithm:
  1. Timer tasks.
  2. on[MessageName].
  3. issueCommand.
  4. getNextCommittedCommand
Exceptions thrown during RaftAlgorithm calls are caught at these entry points. The only situations otherwise are those where internal methods can consume the throwable:
  1. without leaving the system in an inconsistent state
  2. and allow subsequent correct operation.
RPCException instances are considered recoverable and RaftAlgorithm will continue to operate in the face of network errors. StorageException instances are considered unrecoverable and are wrapped in a RaftError and rethrown. Clients must not catch RaftError and must not proceed after encountering a RaftError.

RaftAlgorithm

public RaftAlgorithm(Random random,
                     Timer timer,
                     RPCSender sender,
                     Store store,
                     Log log,
                     RaftListener listener,
                     String self,
                     Set<String> cluster)
Constructor.

This constructor uses default values from RaftConstants for all timeouts.

Parameters:
random - Random used to generate message ids, timeout intervals, etc.
timer - Timer used to schedule schedule tasks for future execution
sender - RPCSender used to send Raft messages to other Raft servers in the Raft cluster
store - Store in which Raft metadata is durably persisted
log - Log in which LogEntry instances are durably persisted
listener - RaftListener that will be notified every time a Command is committed and can be consumed by the client
self - unique id of the local Raft server that instantiated this RaftAlgorithm instance
cluster - immutable set of unique ids of all the Raft servers in the Raft cluster. cluster must include self
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the cluster configuration is malformed

RaftAlgorithm

public RaftAlgorithm(Random random,
                     Timer timer,
                     RPCSender sender,
                     Store store,
                     Log log,
                     RaftListener listener,
                     String self,
                     Set<String> cluster,
                     long rpcTimeout,
                     long minElectionTimeout,
                     long additionalElectionTimeoutRange,
                     long heartbeatInterval,
                     TimeUnit timeoutTimeUnit)
Constructor.

This constructor allows custom values to be specified for all timeouts.

Parameters:
random - Random used to generate message ids, timeout periods, etc.
timer - Timer used to schedule schedule tasks for future execution
sender - RPCSender used to send Raft messages to other Raft servers in the Raft cluster
store - Store in which Raft metadata is durably persisted
log - Log in which LogEntry instances are durably persisted
listener - RaftListener that will be notified every time a Command is committed and can be consumed by the client
self - unique id of the local Raft server that instantiated this RaftAlgorithm instance
cluster - immutable set of unique ids of all the Raft servers in the Raft cluster. cluster must include self
rpcTimeout - time after which a Raft server expects a response (RequestVoteReply, AppendEntriesReply) to its RPC request (RequestVote, AppendEntries)
minElectionTimeout - minimum time after which a follower Raft server will initiate a new election cycle if it does not hear from the leader of the current election term
additionalElectionTimeoutRange - upper bound to the random amount of time added to minElectionTimeout to generate a random election timeout total
heartbeatInterval - time interval after which the leader server will send an AppendEntries message. The next interval starts only after all messages from the previous interval have been sent
timeoutTimeUnit - TimeUnit in which all timeouts are specified
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if either the cluster configuration is malformed or the timeout configuration is invalid
Method Detail

initialize

public void initialize()
                throws StorageException
Initialize the RaftAlgorithm instance

Following a successful call to initialize a call to start() can be made. Any exception thrown by this method indicates that this RaftAlgorithm instance should not be used.

Throws:
StorageException

start

public void start()
Start the RaftAlgorithm instance.

Following a successful call to start() RaftAlgorithm can process incoming Raft messages, participate in the Raft distributed consensus algorithm and (if leader), propose client commands for inclusion in the replicated log. This method is a noop if the system has already been started.

The recommended ordering to start this component and its dependencies/dependents is:

  1. store
  2. log
  3. listener
  4. sender
  5. timer
  6. raftAlgorithm <-- this component

stop

public void stop()
Stop the RaftAlgorithm instance.

If any method call is already in progress it will complete. All pending timeouts are cancelled and no more will be scheduled. Any messages still inbound via RPCReceiver are dropped silently.

If this server is the leader server all incomplete futures returned by Raft.submitCommand(io.libraft.Command) will be cancelled. This does not indicate that the client Command was not replicated. Clients should use application-level protocols to determine how much progress was made before the call to stop(). Subsequent calls to Raft.submitCommand(io.libraft.Command) will throw an IllegalStateException.

public void onAppendEntries(String server,
                            long term,
                            long commitIndex,
                            long prevLogIndex,
                            long prevLogTerm,
                            @Nullable
                            Collection<LogEntry> entries)
Description copied from interface: RPCReceiver
Indicates that an AppendEntries was received.

Specified by:
onAppendEntries in interface RPCReceiver
Parameters:
server - unique id of the Raft server that sent this message
term - election term in which this message was sent
commitIndex - index of the last LogEntry that server believes is committed. commitIndex may be >= the local Raft server's log length even after all entries are successfully appended
prevLogIndex - index of the LogEntry immediately before the first LogEntry in entries
prevLogTerm - election term in which the LogEntry at prevLogIndex was created
entries - sequence of monotonic, gapless, LogEntry instances with indices prevLogIndex + 1, prevLogIndex + 2 .. prevLogIndex + entries.count(). May be null if this AppendEntries message is a heartbeat
See Also:
LogEntry

onAppendEntriesReply

public void onAppendEntriesReply(String server,
                                 long term,
                                 long prevLogIndex,
                                 long entryCount,
                                 boolean applied)
Description copied from interface: RPCReceiver
Indicates that an AppendEntriesReply was received. This is a response to previously-sent AppendEntries message.

Specified by:
onAppendEntriesReply in interface RPCReceiver
Parameters:
server - unique id of the server that sent this message
term - election term in which this message was sent
prevLogIndex - index of the LogEntry after which log entries were meant to be appended
entryCount - number of log entries meant to be appended to the source server's log. 0, if this is a response to a heartbeat
applied - true if the log prefix uniquely defined by (prevLogIndex, prevLogTerm) in the AppendEntries request matched and the Raft server was able to append the entries prevLogIndex + 1 to prevLogIndex + entryCount to its log. false otherwise

Description copied from interface: Raft
Get the next committed Command with a log index after indexToSearchFrom.

Specified by:
getNextCommittedCommand in interface Raft
Parameters:
indexToSearchFrom - index >= 0 after which to search for committed Command instances in the local server's Raft log. indexToSearch should meet the following criteria: 0 <= indexToSearch <= lastLogIndex
Returns:
an instance of CommittedCommand if the local server's Raft log contains a committed command after indexToSearchFrom. null otherwise

submitCommand

public com.google.common.util.concurrent.ListenableFuture<Void> submitCommand(Command command)
                                                                       throws NotLeaderException
Description copied from interface: Raft
Submit an object to be replicated to the cluster.

Specified by:
submitCommand in interface Raft
Parameters:
command - Command instance to be replicated
Returns:
a future that will be triggered when command is replicated or when the command may not have been replicated

If this future is successful, the command is guaranteed to have been replicated to the Raft cluster. There are no false positives.

This future may fail if the system does not know if command was durably replicated or not. There may be false negatives.

Due to message losses this future may not be triggered in a timely manner. Clients should:

  • Not perform indefinite blocking waits on this future.
  • Be prepared to resubmit the command in case of timeouts.
  • Ensure that up-call code can detect and discard duplicate commands.
Throws:
NotLeaderException - if the current Raft server is not the leader. The client can call NotLeaderException.getLeader() to find out which Raft server (if any) is the current leader
